ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: mmat version
Report Generater version
number of reflectors
a new unique event begins when this amount of distance is moved.
Camera version
motion tracking system model
motion trasking system version
dummy variable for future description of MTS version
percentage of time reflector is detected within frame
percentage of time reflector is detected
Percentage of correct responses to both the targets and non-targets
Percentage of time the patient failed to respond to the target. Omission errors measure the patient's level of distraction and/or degree of inattention
Percentage of incorrect responses made to the non-targets. Commission errors are a measure of the patient's impulsivity or inability to inhibit a response
Mean reaction time to respond to a target
Variation (standard deviation) in response times to the correct target. High levels of variability indicate that the patient is inconsistent in the task performance
Variability that is adjusted to take into account difference in response latency. (COV = (100 * Variability) / Latency). This is a more stringent measure of response consistency.
Average time not moving greater than 1 mm - based on head reflector
Average number of position changes >1 mm - based on head relfector
Total distance traveled by the head reflector
Two-dimensional space in which the head reflector moved
Describes the complexity of the movement path. Low spatial complexity values would indicate simple/back-and-forth movements
Frequency of movement with values from 0 to 1. Infrequent movements with long periods of inactivity yield values close to 0. Incessant movement produces values close to 1.
Average time not moving greater than 1 mm - based on left shin reflector
Average number of position changes >1 mm - based on left shin relfector
Total distance traveled by the left shin reflector
Two-dimensional space in which the left shin reflector moved
Describes the complexity of the movement path. Low spatial complexity values would indicate simple/back-and-forth movements
Frequency of movement with values from 0 to 1. Infrequent movements with long periods of inactivity yield values close to 0. Incessant movement produces values close to 1.
Average time not moving greater than 1 mm - based on right shin reflector
Average number of position changes >1 mm - based on right shin relfector
Total distance traveled by the right shin reflector
Two-dimensional space in which the right shin reflector moved
Describes the complexity of the movement path. Low spatial complexity values would indicate simple/back-and-forth movements
Frequency of movement with values from 0 to 1. Infrequent movements with long periods of inactivity yield values close to 0. Incessant movement produces values close to 1.
Describes the attention states of the participant throughout the task.
Count of the number of attention state shifts during the test.
"Percent of the time patient is attentive/on task, i.e., hits many targets and few non-targets"
Percent of the time patient is distracted - misses some targets and hits some non-targets with accuracy better than chance
Percent of the time patient is impulsive hits many targets and some non-targets
Percent of the time patient exhibits random behavior (hits most targets and non-targets with accuaracy about as good as chance.
Percent of time patient misses most targets and non-targets with accuracy about as good a chance
Percent of time patient does significantly worse than chance
